text: The Leader of the Opposition has shown that he cannot accept the letter of the Commissioner of Taxation in which he makes it perfectly plain that there was no tax liability, and no tax liability under the recoupment legislation currently before this Parliament. The Leader of the Opposition issued a statement saying that he was thoroughly dissatisfied with the letter on the day, or the day after, it was published. He sought to introduce other and different issues. He sought to confuse this House with his wet Slutzkins and dry Slutzkins. Let me try to explain why there is a very substantial difference between these practices. Bottomof-the-harbour taxation schemes involve companies with current tax liabilities, which remained unpaid and which remain unpaid to this day, and which will be collected when the current legislation which is before the Parliament is passed by the Parliament. In addition, bottom-of the-harbour schemes are fraudulent in nature on the part of at least one person taking part in the operations. Quite plainly, the Leader of the Opposition is trying to introduce into this Parliament a quite impossible proposition; namely, that any person who had at any time participated in any tax minimisation proposal which was subsequently outlawed by this Parliament and by legislation passed through this Parliament, or which was caught by section 4A of the general anti-avoidance provisions, would, therefore, not be a fit and proper person to hold public office. I suggest that that is an impossible proposition because practices change. This Government, and only this Government, has legislated time and again to outlaw improper taxation practices. If the Leader of the Opposition proposes to legislate at some point retrospectively or believes there ought to be retrospective legislation to collect alleged back tax in relation to all those schemes which have since been outlawed, obviously that is a total and absolute impossibility. The Leader of the Opposition ought to be pressed to define what he means when he says that the Government's legislation does not go far enough, that he wants it to go further, and that he would collect additional sums from other tax minimisation proposals which have since been outlawed. The dry Slutzkin scheme was one in which company tax had been paid and no liability remained. The High Court has upheld that such schemes are in fact lawful. The Leader of the Opposition sought to impute in his motion that Mr John Reid had been involved in bottom-of-theharbour operations; that was the clear implication. It was just as clear as the implication that he made when he wanted certain names to be put together as a result of comments he made in relation to the Costigan Royal Commission report on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. There is only one reason that Mr Reid's name has been used in this Parliament. There is only one reason that this smear has been introduced into the Parliament. It is because Mr John Reid agreed to serve on a review in relation to the Commonwealth Public Service. It is worth noting the response to the charge which was made in the Parliament. Mr Reid immediately stood aside. He wrote to the Commissioner of Taxation giving authority for full information to be made available. Speaker: Mr DA WKINS
Title: DEPUTY COMMISSIONER OF TAXATION
text: The Prime Minister has been cornered and he is now digging in behind tax dodgers and tax dodging. That is very much more characteristic for the Prime Minister who has always been partial to a tax dodge, it being his Government which has introduced more tax rorts of one kind or another mainly to seek to advance its own favoured friends. Many of the particular tax rorts which have been introduced have ended up blowing up in his face. It has subsequently had to fix them up as their manifest inadequacies have been revealed. But what the Prime Minister is in fact seeking to do, and the only thing which he did do in the 20 minutes which was available to him, was to say that there is rarely some tax dodging which is okay and other forms of tax dodging which are not okay. What we want to know from the Prime Minister is simply this: The Leader of the Opposition has indicated he has tabled papers which indicate Mr Reid was associated with certain companies. The Leader of the Opposition has indicated, and I will again, that those companies were organised in such a way, or appear to have been organised in such a way, as to bestow certain tax advantages on either the companies, the shareholders or the people the directors are representing. What we want to know from the Prime Minister is: Were any of those six companies, of which Mr Reid was the director, involved in any kind of tax dodging against which this Government has already acted? Were those companies involved in any schemes which this Government has now outlawed? Is he prepared to answer that question? If he does answer it and if the answer is in the affirmative he seems to be saying that certain schemes, such as the dry Slutzkin scheme, are okay as long as they were carried out prior to the time the Government legislated. That is not what the Government has been ranting and raving about. It is certainly not what the Prime Minister has been ranting and raving about in recent times. I refer the Prime Minister to the I October edition of the Sydney Morning Herald in which he is quoted as saying: But are we governed only by law? Is there not a question of ethics? Is there not a question of honour in the way in which people do their business? If every wrongful act has to be proscribed by law, then we're really going to be so circumscribed by laws, that you'll need a couple of solicitors behind you at every step and I don't particularly want to live in that kind of society. In this instance the Prime Minister is not simply talking about what is strictly within the law at a particular time; he is talking about what is ethical and what is moral. Let us take this debate back to the circumstances in which it arose. The Prime Minister, in order to distract attention from the very glaring criticism of the Government in relation to its procrastination on tax dodging, said he was setting up an inquiry into the Public Service, as if the Public Service had something to do with the Government's procrastination when it was quite clear that the Commisisoner of Taxation had increasingly been going spare about the fact that the Government would not act on any of his advice in relation to tax avoidance schemes. On that occasion the Prime Minister said: The third challenge, I regret to say, arises from a deterioration in what I might call the 'business There was a time when the administration, with business, could assume that propriate. The Service did not have to be geared to handle cheating on a large scale . . . He then referred to the Service's inability to respond speedily and adequately to the challenges posed by those who seek to behave unethically or even illegally. He said: Those in the community who cheat on their obligations to others or attempt dishonestly to evade the law, whether by evading taxation . . . not only bring dishonour to themselves but also impose real strains on the Public Service The Prime Minister wants to set up an inquiry which can ensure that the Public Service, as a result, can be in better shape to deal with these tax cheats. Therefore, I would have thought that it was beyond argument that the people involved in that inquiry, particularly the person who was to lead it, should be entirely above reproach on any of those matters. We are not talking about some strict definition of law breaking. The Prime Minister has not sought to use that on other occasions. We are talking about morality, business ethics and cheating. What has the Prime Minister been saying about some of those things? He went to Kingston recently. I am sure that he will not be invited back by the current honourable member for Kingston (Mr Chapman). He certainly will not be around when the next member for Kingston is in this House. What the Prime Minister said to the rapt audience of businessmen at Kingston was that he was talking about people who were trying to get rid of companies that had a tax liability to the Commonwealth to the benefit of the shareholders. There is no question about there being some strict distinction between company tax and money in the hands of the shareholders which would otherwise have been destined for the Federal Treasury. He was talking about schemes which avoid the tax liability of companies to the benefit of shareholders. He said: In a real sense, the recipients of those funds have in their hands stolen funds, whether you want to say stolen from the Commonwealth or stolen from other taxpayers He was not saying that only the money that has been ripped off the Treasury in relation to company taxes is stolen money; he was talking about all of it as being stolen money and those people who have it as being the recipients of stolen money. He continued: In relation to tax avoidance, I have said on other occasions and other places that people who pursue and generally people of wealth who pursue practices which only result in the cheating of the Commonwealth or the cheating of the generality of the Australian public in a highly sophisticated way in which wealthy people often become wealthier, is something totally ethics' of a minority. un-Australian-·in its relationships a high degree of trust was apIn recent times we have seen the Prime Minister in great form thundering denunciation of tax avoidance of any kind. Now he is seeking to justify that certain activities and certain kinds of theft which are involved in denying the Treasury money which was due to it are okay as far as he is concerned. That is not the view of the Treasurer (MrHoward). It will be remembered that these six companies had already embarked on the process of liquidation. If that liquidation had pursued its full course the shareholders who received the distributed assets of those companies would have been taxed, in their own hands, that part of the distributed assets of the company which represented profits from former years. That is the process on which these companies have embarked-to liquidate and to distribute their assets, and then the shareholders would have been liable for tax in their own hands. Mysteriously, in February of 1977, that course of action was changed. It was perhaps changed for the reason that in February 1977 the Barwick High Court, which has accurately been described at that time as the tax avoiders temple, had given a decision in relation to the Slutzkin case. What the High Court had said was that to engage in certain artificial practices in order to avoid tax was okay. At the same time as that judgment was brought down these six companies altered their course and pursued an entirely different course which resulted in shareholders avoiding a substantial part of the tax liability which they would have incurred had those companies been liquidated in the normal way. In 1978 the Treasurer clamped down on some of these aspects which had been revealed by the Slutzkin scheme and particularly by the High Court decision of the time. At that time the Treasurer said of these schemes which we are now talking about: However the Government believes that some techniques of tax avoidance---Tax avoidance not tax evasionare so blatant and contrived and artificial as to go beyond the bounds of reasonableness. What the Treasurer was talking about, and he was absolutely right at the time, was that any scheme which involved the artificial avoidance of a tax liability was unacceptable to the Government. Regrettably it took the Government until 1981 to move on the particular aspect of these schemes which allowed shareholders to receive the benefits of those companies and not pay tax on them. The Government cannot have it both ways. The Prime Minister cannot continue to claim that this Government has an unparalleled record in relation to clamping down on tax avoidance schemes and at the same time say that the people who were involved in the schemes were really not doing anything wrong. The Government simply cannot have it both ways. We have identified and had tabled in this Parliament details of 22 schemes which this Government has outlawed during the last few years. Those 22 schemes are in the blatantly artificial and contrived category of which the Treasurer was so critical in 1978. This is the kind of scheme in which Mr Reid was involved. I have indicated that had the process of liquidation continued the shareholders would have been liable for tax. Apparently as a result of resorting to different procedures in relation to getting rid of these companies the amount of tax which was saved in 1977 dollars was over $43,000, which in current day terms is $76,000. We are not suggesting that Reid is in Horgan's category. We are not suggesting that Reid is the worse tax dodger in the country. What we are saying is that, quite clearly, the companies with which Mr Reid was associated were involved in avoiding tax to the tune of $43,000 for their shareholders at the time. He is not on that evidence a fit person to lead this inquiry.
